investor_info.name: Warren Buffett
investor_info.title: Chairman & CEO, Berkshire Hathaway
investor_info.investment_philosophy: Value investing with focus on companies with strong competitive advantages, good management, and reasonable prices
famous_quotes: It's far better to buy a wonderful company at a fair price than a fair company at a wonderful price.
Rule No. 1: Never lose money. Rule No. 2: Never forget Rule No. 1.
In the business world, the rearview mirror is always clearer than the windshield.

insights.content: Apple has a consumer product that is extraordinarily sticky. People love their iPhone. The whole ecosystem is incredible. And we own a good chunk of it.
insights.context: Discussing Berkshire's investment in Apple and its consumer moat

insights.content: Coca-Cola is a business that sells 1.9 billion servings a day. That's a business you can understand. It's a simple business that works worldwide.
insights.context: Explaining why Coca-Cola is a quintessential Buffett investment

insights.content: We're buying banks at prices that look attractive. The banking business is generally a good business if you don't do dumb things. Wells Fargo has made some mistakes, but we still believe in the franchise.
insights.context: Discussing Berkshire's bank holdings despite Wells Fargo scandals

insights.content: Amazon is a remarkable business. Bezos has done incredible things. We missed it early because it was harder to value than things we typically buy, but you can't argue with the results.
insights.context: Admitting missing Amazon but praising the business

insights.content: See's Candies taught us about brand power. We bought it for $25 million in 1972, and it has earned over $2 billion since. That's the power of a strong brand with pricing power.
insights.context: Using See's Candies as example of brand power and pricing power

insights.content: The airline business has been terrible for investors over the years, but we've made a bet because consolidation has improved the industry economics. It's still a tough business.
insights.context: Explaining investment in major U.S. airlines

insights.content: I don't understand Bitcoin. It doesn't produce anything. You're hoping the next guy pays more. I'm not interested. We buy businesses that make things or provide services.
We like businesses that earn high returns on capital. That's the Holy Grail. Apple earns incredible returns on capital, and they don't need much capital to grow.
